title: Integration Studio—Asset Manager to Service Management demo data import
content:
The Integration Studio provides the capability to import data from Asset Manager (AM) to Service Management. A set of templates are also available to ease the data import from Asset Manager to the corresponding Service Management record types.

This capability is not designed for the migration of an Asset Manager system to Service Management. You can use it only for demonstration purposes and only for partial data import.
The integration use cases described in this document serve as examples to inspire and guide your integration efforts. However, they should not be considered as prescriptive or guaranteed solutions for your particular scenario. The examples may or may not be applicable for your license edition.


Supported record types

This capability supports data import for the following objects or record types, and you can customize the system to support additional objects / record types.

Financial module

  • Budget

  • Budget Line

  • Budget Center

  • Budget Type

  • Cost Center

  • Cost Type

  • Fiscal Year

  • Accounting Period

Procurement

  • Vendor

  • Vendor catalog

  • Vendor catalog item

  • Brand

SACM

  • Asset Model

  • Computer

  • Monitor

Master Data

  • Location

  • Group

  • Person

  • Stock room

Before you start

To successfully use the provided solution, the following prerequisites must be met.

Expertise

Ensure you have knowledge and experience in the following technological areas of the two products:

Asset Manager

The database structure and the following modules:

  • Asset lifecycle > Infrastructure management > Portfolio items
  • Asset lifecycle > IT services and virtualization > Business services
  • Asset lifecycle > IT financial management > Budgets
  • Asset lifecycle > IT financial management > Cost tracking
  • Asset lifecycle > Supplier contract management > Leasing
  • Asset lifecycle > Supplier contract management > Contracts
  • Organization management > Organization > Companies
  • Organization management > Organization > Employees
  • Organization management > Organization > Employees and departments
  • Organization management > Organization > Locations
  • Organization management > Operations > Employee groups
  • Organization management > Operations > Stocks
  • Portfolio management > Asset configurations > IT equipment
  • Portfolio management > Asset configurations > Models
  • Portfolio management > Asset configurations > Natures
  • Portfolio management > Catalog > Brands
  • Portfolio management > Catalog > Catalog references
  • Portfolio management > Catalog > Catalogs

For more information, see Asset Manager online documentation.

Service Management

  • The Studio, especially how to manage the database attributes in the records section and the forms
  • The Service Management database structure, especially ENTITY_LINKS between database entities
  • The list feature (ENUM) to find the correct values for drop-down lists
  • The EMS and Manage Persons REST APIs
  • The Integration Studio
  • The following asset management-related modules:
    • Plan > Contract
    • Plan > Company
    • Build > Service Asset and Configuration
    • Build > Procurement
    • Run > Software Asset
    • Run > Financials
    • Administration > People
    • Administration > Locations

Supported versions

Asset Manager 9.80 or later

Network connectivity

To connect from Service Management to Asset Manager, the following options exist:

  • Run Service Management and Asset Manager in the same network to directly connect the two systems.
  • Use the On-Premises Bridge to connect. For example, from a Service Management SaaS environment to an Asset Manager in the customer's data center.

We recommend running Service Management and Asset Manager on the same network.

Cloud/On-Premises

If Service Management runs in a cloud/on-premises environment, the connectivity depends on your network settings. If an HTTP connection can be established between the 2 systems, you can use the solution directly; if not, consider using the On-Premises Bridge.

Key concepts

To effectively use this solution, you need to understand the following concepts.

Nature vs. Record type

In Asset Manager, most of the managed items are called “portfolio items”. Each item has a “nature” that defines what this item is. The fields of a portfolio item might be saved into an “overflow table” depending on its nature, such as the amAsset table and amCompute table.

In Service Management, the corresponding concept is “record type”. Different record types have different fields and life cycles (workflows). For more information on record types, see the Service Management documentation regarding Studio.

To migrate a record from AM to Service Management, the first step is to decide its nature, that is, the corresponding record type in Service Management.

Example:

Dependencies and migration sequence

The data model in AM is relational. The relationships between the AM records are built via the foreign key at the database level. Service Management also uses the rational data model. Each record has a unique ID. Cross-entity references are built via this unique ID. However, Service Management doesn’t force referential integrity at the database level. This means that in most cases, we can first create the record in Service Management, and then set up the relationships between the records.

In Service Management,when you create some records, the system doesn't verify whether the relationship field is empty or not. We can check if the validation is performed by a business rule and whether this rule can be temporarily disabled in the migration process. If not, the field is a “hard” dependency. We must first migrate the related item first.

Unidirectional relation

In Service Management,the basic relations are unidirectional. For example, an accounting period references a fiscal year.

In this case, we recommend that you follow this migration sequence:

  1. Migrate Fiscal Year
  2. Migrate Accounting Period and set up its reference to the Fiscal Year at the same time

Bidirectional relation and loop relation

In Service Management,there’re bidirectional relations and loop relations. For example, the organization of the Person record is a “Group”, and the owner of the Group record is a “Person.”

In this case, we recommend that you follow this migration sequence:

  1. Migrate Person, and at this time, keep the Person’s organization empty
  2. Migrate Organization, and at this time, set the Group’s owner because Person has already been migrated
  3. Update Person again, which sets up only the relationship of Organization because Group has been migrated

Self-reference

Sometimes, a record will reference another record with the same record type. We call this a self-reference relation. For example, a cost center might have a parent cost center.

In this case, we recommend that you follow this migration sequence: Migrate Cost Center order by level, starting with the lowest level

Dependencies between record types

The following image shows the related record types in Service Management. To reduce updates, we recommend that you migrate the record types by business module. The following migration sequence is recommended but it’s not mandatory: Financial > Master data > Procurement > SACM > SAM > Contract.

Reconciliation key

The reconciliation key is a field available on both the AM record and the Service Management record. It relates an AM record to its corresponding record in Service Management. For example, both Asset Manager and Service Management have the “BarCode” information on a device. The migration script might need to run repeatedly. In this case, you can use the reconciliation key to distinguish whether the CREATE or UPDATE action is required. Also, to set up a relationship (entity link or many-to-many association) between records, you must first define the reconciliation key for each record.

The reconciliation key should be unique, immutable, non-null, and human-readable and doesn’t contain special characters (such as “&”, space, and “%”).

Data model mapping

Most records in Service Management can find their peers in AM tables. For example, you can find the peer for “Device” from the amCompute table, and the peer for “Asset Model” from the amModel table. The fields of these records can also be mapped from the corresponding AM table. 

The mapping descriptions are provided based on the out-of-the-box (OOTB) data model of AM and Service Management. However, the data structure of Service Management and Asset Manager might be different, especially for a customized AM system. In this case:

  • If you want to migrate a field that is not available in Service Management from AM, you can use Service Management Studio to create a field. See Create a field.
  • If you want to migrate a record type that is not available in Service Management from AM, you can use Service Management Studio to create a record type.

Data inapplicable to migration

Due to the limitations of EMS APIs, some data might not be migrated. Data that isn’t applicable to this migration solution includes:

  • Data stored in satellite tables in EMS, such as expense lines.
  • Cost allocation rules: The rules implemented in Service Management are different from those in AM. We recommend that you reimplement the rules.
  • Data coming from third-party systems, such as fixed assets and purchase orders/lines.
  • Fields whose data type in Service Management is Complex Type, such as the History field of each record or the CPUs field of the Device record. The Attachment field doesn’t belong to this case.

Prepare Service Management

To be able to import the data from Asset Manager into Service Management,the following steps are required.

Prepare an integration user for your Service Management tenant

Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user:

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user. 
  2. Assign the Tenant Admin role to the new Integration User.

Create an agent (optional)

In case the connection to the Asset Manager system is using the On-Premises Bridge, create an Agent in Service Management first.

Create an endpoint

Create an endpoint by using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.
  3. Click Add.
  4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint, and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.

  5. Click Configure and complete the following fields.

    FieldValue

    Agent

    Select your On-Premises Bridge agent if required. Select agentless to connect directly to the system.

    Authentication type

    Select Basic.

    Protocol

    Select https.

    Base URL

    Enter the base URL of the Asset Manager System: https://<FQDN>:port

    Credentials

    (only visible when an Agent is selected)

    Select the credentials configured in the On-Premises Bridge

    Username

    (only visible when Agentless is selected)

    Enter the username of the Asset Manager user

    Note: The user to connect to Asset Manager must have “Admin” rights.

    Password

    (only visible when Agentless is selected)

    Enter the password of the Asset Manager user.

    Confirm password

    (only visible when Agentless is selected)

    Re-enter the password.

    Certificate type

    (only visible when Agentless is selected)

    Select X.509.

    Certificate format

    (only visible when Agentless is selected)

    Select PEM.

    Server certificate

    (only visible when Agentless is selected)

    Copy the content of the CA certificate authority into this field.

    You can get the root certificate from the SaaS operations team.

Create an Integration

Create an integration and configure one or more scenarios to define the logic to import data from Asset Manager into Service Management.

To create an integration:

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
  2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
  3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
  5. Select Asset Manager (under OpenText) as the connector, select the Asset Manager endpoint that you created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
  6. Click Save.

Configure the scenarios

Most of the scenarios are pre-configured to directly run them without the need of any modifications.

Perform the following steps to add the scenarios to the integration:

  1. Click Add scenario.
  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter 01 Import Fiscal Years.
  3. In the Template field, select 01 Import Fiscal Years (under OpenText Asset Manager) from the list.
  4. Click Save to add the scenario.
  5. Repeat the steps above to add the rest of the scenarios listed in the section below, in the order they're listed.
: The scenarios are defined and tested with an out-of-the box Asset Manager. If you use an out-of-the box Asset Manager, you don't need to do anything before starting the import. In case your system is heavily customized, you may want to review and adjust the scenarios first.

Run the scenarios

Once your integration and scenarios are ready, click Run scenario to start importing data from Asset Manager. Run them in the following order.

  1. 01 Import Fiscal Years
  2. 02 Import Accounting Periods
  3. 03 Import Budget Centers
  4. 04 Import Budget Types
  5. 05 Import Budgets
  6. 06 Import Budget Lines
  7. 07 Import Cost Centers
  8. 08 Import Cost Types
  9. 09 Import Locations
  10. 10 Import Groups
  11. 11 Import People
  12. 12 Import Vendors
  13. 13 Import Brands
  14. 14 Import Vendor Catalog
  15. 15 Import Vendor Catalog Items
  16. 16 Import Asset Models
  17. 17 Import Stock Room
  18. 18 Import Computers
  19. 19 Import Monitors

To ensure the references between the records are correctly set, we recommend starting the next scenario only when the current scenario is finished.

: Some entities, where cross reference data is required, may have to be imported more than once to correctly set all related data.

In-dept explanation of a scenario

Each scenario is following the same principles.

  1. Get data from Asset Manager.
  2. Iterate through the data, and do the following:
    1. Prepare the data as required in Service Management.
    2. Create or update the record in Service Management.

Example:

Get data from Asset Manager

To get data from Asset Manager, click the + Add Rule button. Select the Get Record(s) action from the Target Asset Manager. The rule is now added to the scenario. Now, configure the input parameters of the new rule.

ParameterComment

Input - Filter

A query parameter to filter records in the Asset Manager table. It is a raw AQL WHERE clause.

Input – Order By

A query parameter to order the results by this field. Note: If this is not an index field, the sorting might take a lot of time.

Input - Limit

A query parameter to specify the maximum number of records to be retrieved. The default is 100.

Input - Offset

A query parameter to specify the number of records to be ignored. The default is 0.

Input – Table Name

The Asset Manager table from which to get the data.

Input - Fields

A query parameter to specify a comma-separated list of fields to be included in the response. See the Asset Manager help for valid field names.

Output

You can define the output based on your needs. In these scenarios, we always parse the response from Asset Manager into different parameters for further usage in the scenario.

How to process the Asset Manager response

The key “entities” in the Asset Manager response contains all data. The output of the first rule parses the “entities” key from the AM JSON response into the “Entities” parameter.

Now, as the next step, we use the output parameter as Input for the iterator.

Within the iterator rule, you can reference each element in the array with the keyword “item”. For example “item.Start”.

The “Prepare Data” rule returns the object “Data”, with the configured elements.

Scenario details

Fiscal Years

The fiscal year import is managed in the scenario “01 Import Fiscal Years”.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lFinYearId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Accounting Periods

The Accounting Periods import is managed in the scenario “02 Import Accounting Periods”. The reference to the accounting period is created.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lPeriodId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

AccountingPeriodToFiscalYear

The ID of the Fiscal Year record in Service Management.

Budget Centers

The Budget Center import is managed in the scenario “03 Import Budget Centers”. The parent/child relation between budget centers is kept.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lBudgCntrId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

ParentBudgetCenter

The Service Management record ID of the parent budget center record.

Budget Types

The Budget Type import is managed in the scenario “04 Import Budget Types”.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lBudgCatId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Budgets

The Budget import is managed in the scenario “05 Import Budgets”.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lBudgId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

UsedByBudgetCenter

The Service Management record ID of the budget center record.

Budget Lines

The Budget Line import is managed in the scenario “06 Import Budget Lines”.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lBudgLineId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Category

The Service Management record ID of the budget type.

BudgetLineToBudget

The Service Management record ID of the budget.

AccountingPeriod

The Service Management record ID of the Accounting period.

Cost Centers

The Cost Center import is managed in the scenario “07 Import Cost Centers”.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lCostId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Manager

The Service Management record ID of the person. Queried based on the Email address.

Parent

The Service Management record ID of the parent cost center.

CostCenterToBudgetCenter

The Service Management record ID of the Budget Center.

Cost Type

The Cost Type import is managed in the scenario “08 Import Cost Types”.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lRelCCatClassId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Code

Is a concatenated string of AM BudgetCategory.Code and CostCategory.Code

UsedByBudgetType

The Service Management record ID of the budget type.

Location

The Location import is managed in the scenario “09 Import Locations”.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Code

This field is populated with the AM key (lLocaId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

ParentLocation

The Service Management record ID of the parent location.

Groups

The Group import is managed in the scenario “10 Import Groups”. Group members are not imported.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

UPN

This field is populated with the AM key (Name) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Persons

The current OOTB configuration for this scenario creates Contacts in Service Management (not actual Users). This setting would need amending for users after the import is completed, if a Person record should indeed be an agent user.

The Person import is managed in the scenario “11 Import Persons”. 

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

UPNThe UPN is set to the email of the user, hence the email must be populated in Asset Manager.
EmployeeIDThe AM UserId is stored in the Employee Id field. 

Vendors

The Vendors import is managed in the scenario “12 Import Vendors”. 

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Company TypeTo import companies from AM to Service Management, it’s important that the Company Type field matches the data in the Service Management ENUM List named CompanyTypeEnum.
Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lCpyId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Brands

The Brands import is managed in the scenario “13 Import Brands”. 

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

OwnedByCompany

In order to import the Brands, the scenario relies upon the Name field in the Company Record. The scenario can then look up if a company exists or not, and if so, create the link for the OwnedbyCompany relationship, which is a required field.

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (Name) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Vendor Catalog

The Vendor Catalog import is managed in the scenario “14 Import Vendor Catalog”. 

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Owner

The updated Vendor Catalog scenario uses the Employee Id to do a look up in order to set the Supervisor value to the Owner field in Service Management. If the Import People Scenario is updated to use a different field for the AM UserId, this needs to be used here in the Owner field, in order for this link to be created.

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lCatalogId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Vendor

Additional logic that can be built in, is to make an assumption that the distributor value from AM could be mapped to the Vendor in Service Management. When the Company import was done, the AM Company ID value was added into Service Management. It's then possible to lookup this value and set the Vendor for the Vendor Catalog.

Vendor Catalog Item

The Vendor Catalog Item import is managed in the scenario “15 Import Vendor Catalog Item”. 

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lCatRefId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

ExpiryDate

The expiry date is pulled, but if the Start of Validity date in AM is required, then a new field in Service Management needs to be created first and then the scenario amended to include this.

The minimum order quantity can also be pulled across.

CurrencyValue

At present there is no means to pull the Currency value over. The Currency in AM is held in another reference, so there is no actual data to pull out and then attempt to match up with ENUM in Service Management.

ListPriceThe List Price is currently the value from the Price field in AM. If this should be the Vendor Price, then the scenario should be modified to fit this requirement.

Asset Models

The Asset Models import is managed in the scenario “16 Import Asset Models”. 

Currently there is a Business Rule on the Asset Model record in Service Management that will prevent any Asset Models from being created if the Asset Type field is empty and the Category is false. 

By disabling this rule, it’s then possible to import all Asset Models from Asset Manager.

Two options are available:

  • Disable the rule and import all Asset models from the amModel table

  • Import based upon Natures in AM

This Scenario uses the Natures within AM to help build out the Asset Models in Service Management by using a number of IF/Else statements.

By using this logic, it helps to build out Device, Infrastructure & Peripheral, License, and Enterprise Asset Models. If, after running the scenario lots of errors occur or Models are missing, then it may require you to disable the business rule in Service Management to make sure all the required Asset Models are imported.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lModelId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

Stock Room

The Stock Room import is managed in the scenario “17 Import Stock rooms”. 

This scenario extracts all the Stock Room details such as Location, Owner, and Cost Center and applies this data to the Stock Room records to be created within Service Management.
 
Then when any Assets that are in Stock in AM are imported to Service Management,they'll have the Stockroom linked to that Device or Infrastructure & Peripheral.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (lStockId) and is used as the reconciliation key.

LocationIf the location is found, a link to the location is added.
SupervisorIf the supervisor is found, a link to the supervisor (person) is addded.

Computers

The Computers import is managed in the scenario “18 Import Computers”. 

With AM, the Portfolio Items table is where a certain amount of Device information is held. If the Device is an IT Device, another table amComputer is used to hold additional information about the Portfolio Item. This means first creating the Device from the amPortfolio table, then update the device using the amComputer table.


Certain information can be gathered from the amPortfolio table. However, it's not possible to set the subtype of the Device from this table's output. So initially the subtype would need to be set to unknown, then use the amComputer table to update an already loaded device to fill in the Computer details, as well as setting the correct Subtype.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (PortfolioItemID) and is used as the reconciliation key.

StockroomIf the stock room is found, a link to the Stock room is added.
OwnerIf the owner is found, a link to the owner (person) is addded.
AssetModelIf the Asset Model is found, a link is added.
CostCenterIf the Cost Center is found, a link is added.
CostTypeIf the Cost Type is found, a link is added.

Monitors

The Monitors import is managed in the scenario “18 Import Monitors”. 

In AM, there is special table for Monitors. This scenario is used to pull that information in and create Peripheral devices in Service Management based upon the Assets held in AM.

The following lists some special properties in the CREATE/UPDATE step.

Property

Comment

Id

Mode create: the ID is not required

Mode update: the ID is required

Name

This field is populated with the AM key (PortfolioItemID) and is used as the reconciliation key.

StockroomIf the stock room is found, a link to the Stock room is added.
OwnerIf the owner is found, a link to the owner (person) is addded.
AssetModelIf the Asset Model is found, a link is added.
CostCenterIf the Cost Center is found, a link is added.
CostTypeIf the Cost Type is found, a link is added.
